text: A speedboat cuts swiftly through the ocean swells beneath looming cliffs of ISLA SORNA.
Illegal Costa Rican parasail operator ENRIQUE CARDOSO hel Americans BEN HILDEBRAND and twelve-year-old ERIC KIRVY - already wearing life-vests -- strap themselves into a two person PARASAIL HARNESS.
Ben and Eric clamber onto a makeshift PLATFORM that hangs the back of the board. Dangling from Ben's neck is a CAMC
You make sure to get us as close as you can, okay? If it's a good trip, I'll give you a  little extra.
Don't worry. I take you close. But not too  close. (rubbing Eric's head)
You don't want them to eat you. Enrique heads toward the driver's seat and a large SECOND WINCH bolted to the deck.

Ready, amigos? Ben and Eric nod excitedly and give the thumbs up. Ben li camcorder to the record the action. Enrique jams the down the throttle down, and with a loud speedboat shoots forward. Soon the boat is whipping acros rolling ocean. Strapped together, Ben and Eric lean back over the passin water, intently watching for Enrique's signal. As the boat picks up speed, Enrique eyes the speedometer. Ben grabs the end of the RIPCORD attached to the harness. Eric braces themselves. Enrique finally signals with a pulling motion. He pulls the winch, Ben yanks the cord and -  WOOOSH! A brightly colored PARASAIL blossoms behind the b hoisting Ben and Eric aloft. In a big BLOCK LETTERS on th parasail is stitched "DINO-SOAR." THE TOWNLINE unsold rapidly from its enormous reel. BEN AND ERIC climb higher and higher. ENRIQUE keeps an eye on the clients. When they reach a ce height, he LOCKS OFF the reel. High overhead, Ben and Eric are floating in wonderful, qu splendor. The motor of the boat now sounds strangely dist Down below, the boat enters a think blanket of FOG. Eric points excitedly at the islands as Ben films him wit camera. Then, a sudden TUG on the thing line cause Ben to drop th which now dangles from his neck.

What was that? A second tug...and now the faintest of screams. Ben and Eric look down to find that the boat has disappea into the low bank of FOG. By the time the boat emerges on the far side of the mist. IS NO SIGN OF ENRIQUE. The deck is splattered with blood. As Ben considers the driverless boat...

Ben! Ben glances over at Eric, staring in horror at something  below. Following his gaze, Ben finds that their boat is o moments away from crashing into A LARGE REEF. Sticking out of the water, the imposing reef is being bat by waves. AS THE BOAT SMASHES INTO THE REEF, it splinters into a number of pieces. A panicked Ben turns to Eric.
Unclip your line! Eric and Ben frantically unclip their lines. Catching an updraft, the parasailers float upward. A strong wind sends them wafting over the daunting cliffs of ISLA SORNA...
TWO PLASTIC DINOSAURS enter the frame and do battle accom by a child's ferocious sounds.

CHARLIE, a three-year old boy, plays in a sandbox with hi favorite toy dinosaurs. ALAN GRANT squats next to him and watches with great delight. ELLIE SATLER stands over them, an INFANT in her arms -- a picture of the perfect family.
Oh, actually, Charlie, those two are herbivores. They wouldn't be interested in fighting each other. But these... (picking up two other dinosaurs)

See, these are carnivores. And this one here -- see its claws -- this one here uses its claws to gouge at the throat of its opponent... As Grant demonstrates with some GRUNT and GROANS of his own, he only succeeds in frightening the boy.
(interrupting)
Uh, Alan?
Hmm?
He's three. Why don't you wait till he's a little older?
Oh, right. (back to Charlie)
Happy dinosaurs. He bounces them along the sandbox edge. Then, the sound of a CAR ENGINE turning off and a door SLAMMING is heard.
That must be Mark. (calling out)
Mark, were back here! Ellie and Grant turn to see -- MARK DEGLER coming through the gate carrying a briefcase. balance demeanor. He and Ellie kiss tenderly on the lips.
Good day?
Keeping the world safe. (re: baby)
Here, let me take her. Ellie hands off the baby.
Mark, this is Alan Grant.
Nice to meet you, Alan. I've heard a lot about you. The two men shake hands, and we now realize it is Grant who is the stranger in this household. Little Charlie run his father, showing his dinosaur.
Daddy, this is a herbabore. Grant smiles uncomfortably, a third wheel.
WINDEN to a PARROT in a large cage. Grant is teasing  the bird with a cookie, holding a it just out of reach.
What's my name? Come on, Jack, say it. Is my name Alan? Say my name. The bird doesn't respond.
He used to know me.

Sorry, Alan it's been six years. Grant shrugs, gives Jack the cookie, and heads towards th The three adults are finishing their dessert and coffee. The children have been out to bed. An awkward moment of silence. Uncomfortable smiles. Then
More coffee?
(relived)
Yes. Great. Mark stands and collects their cups.
So, Mark's working at the State Department now.
Really?  (To Mark) What do you do there?
(with mock bravado)
I could tell you about it, but than I'd have to kill you.
Indeed. Mark smiles, nodding. Then he goes into the kitchen. Anot uncomfortable silence.
So what are you working on now?
We have a new site in Montana. At least until the money runs out.
Anything good?
Raptors, mostly.
My favorite. Grant leans forward, realizing Ellie's one of the few peo can talk to about this.
You remember the sounds they made?
I try not to.

We've done cranial scans, and raptors actually had a quite sophisticated resonating chamber. I have a theory that their ability to vocalize is the key to their social intelligence. The way they can work together as a team.
You think they could talk to each other?
To a degree we never imagined. And from the cage in the corner of the room...
Bullshit! Both look back at the parrot. ELLIE smiles.
You taught him that.
Ellie and Grant head toward the rental car parked in the driveway.
Good luck with the fund raising.
It was never easy, but before Jurassic Park, you could find money. Somewhere. Now fossils are out. Everyone wants to see a real live dinosaur.
Times change Alan. But you're the still the best. I mean that.
The last of my breed. A long moment passes between them as both consider where they've ended up.
I'd better get going.
Let me know if I can help, Alan. Youre bad about asking for help, but please ask me. Anything, anytime.
(deep down knowing he never will)
Okay. Goodbye, Ellie.

Goodbye, Alan. Not sure what the right thing to do is, they finally end a friendly hug. They keep it short. Grant gets in his car. Starts the ENGINE. He's about to pull off when Ellie knocks on the window. H it down.

When I met you, I thought that one day millions of years ago, all the dinosaurs became extinct. Wiped out. But you told me otherwise. When conditions changed, dinosaurs changed. They became other things. They evolved.
A well-accepted theory.
(simply)
Alan don't be afraid to evolve. Grant hears her, but Ellie knows it didn't really get thr A forced half-smile, than Grant waves goodbye. Ellie watches as he drives off.

The last stop on Grant's fund-raising tour, it's a public lecture hosted by some foundation. There are SCIENTISTS a STUDENTS here, but also a lot of DINO-FANS, some even wit costumes. Grant finishes his speech to what was a full house -- som ATTENDEES are grabbing their coats and sneaking out. This wasn't the exciting guest speaker they were all expecting A new slide comes up. Just black and white, and indeciphe

It's through the painstaking study of the Interior chamber in multiple specimens that we can determine this exciting correlation between the larynx and the upper plate. That lets us theorize -- theorize, mind you -- that the raptor might have been capable of bird- like vocalizations. Which as you can imagine, would be a tremendous breakthrough. He's finished, but no one seems to notice at first. Then SYMPOSTUM LEADER stands up, leading a smattering round of APPLAUSE.
Thank you very much Dr. Grant. Now does anyone have a question? Nearly every hand goes up. Grant doesn't seem surprised.
Does anyone have a question that doesn't  relate to Jurassic Park? Quite a few hands go down. GRANT (cont'd)
Or the incident in San Diego, which I'll remind you, I did not witness. Now most of the hands are down. Picking one of the few remaining...
Your theory on raptors is good and all, but isn't all this conjecture kind of moot? The STUDENT'S BUDDY nods in agreement.
I mean, once the U.N. and Costa Rica and everyone decides how to handle the second island, scientist will just go in and look for themselves.
Isn't paleontology itself in danger of extinction? Recognizing those as fighting words, the symposium leader about to step in. But Grant will take this himself.
No, and let me be perfectly clear on this point. Dinosaurs lived 65 million years ago. What's left of them is fossilized in stone the actual scientists spend years to undercover.
what John Hammond and InGen created are theme park monsters. Nothing more, nothing less. The class clearly disagrees with his assessment.
You're saying you wouldn't want to study them if you had the chance?
No force on this earth or in heaven could get me on that island.
Looking through the cracked windshield of a junkyard plan see someone spray painting red circles on the outside of glass.

NASH, a wry, intelligent mercenary pilot and soldier, is painting huge eyes the windows of a wrecked plane. Finish tosses the paint can through the open windows and walks q away from the plane. We now see that RED TEETH are painted on the craft's nose looks absurdly like some angry beast. We are one the edge of a dry lake bed, part of an aircraf graveyard. Wrecked planes lie all around. We hear a phone RINGING...
A RINGING satellite phone rests on a stack of gun cases. UDESKY, the leader of this crew, answers it.
Udesky. (beat)
Yes sir. we're good to go. I'll lock it down as soon as you drop me the payment. With the phone still to his ear, Udesky wanders out of th craft...

Udesky looks over at Nash and COOPER, another mercenary. Cooper's the quiet muscle of the bunch, a weapons special finishes loading a massive gun, essentially a hand-cannon aimed at Nash's grimacing aircraft.

That's right, two of the very best I could find. No, I haven't worked with them personally, but they come with the highest recommendations. Then -- Cooper FIRES at the grimacing aircraft. A projectile rock into the plane and EXPLODES with a fireball. Nash and Cooper exchange a satisfied smile.
You've got nothing to worry about, sir. This is going to be a piece of cake. Pieces of the demolished craft come raining down.

location: EXCAVATION BASE CAMP, PT. PECK LAKE, MT -

text: CLOSE ON a man's hand, carefully scraping the stone away dinosaur fossil. We follow his hand back as he wipes off sweaty brow, revealing him to be BILLY BRENNAN, 25, an associate professor and site manager. He's a charmer. Looking past him, we see CHERYL, 21, a junior at junior o of a dozen COLLEGE STUDENTS working at the site, and the most smitten with her supervisor.
Billy? I don't think I'm doing this right. He scoots over, lying down beside her. Checks her work.
You need to go slowly. See, just take it little at a time. She's not listening, just watching his eyelashes.
I can never tell what's bone and what's rock.

Technically, it's all rock. The calcium in the bones is replaced during fossilization. But you can feel the difference. See? Rough, smooth. Rough, smooth. He runs her bare fingers over the two different patches, her. After a pause, she runs her finger along his stubbly chin...
Rough. ...and along his lips. CHERYL (cont'd)
Smooth. Billy may not have started this flirtation, but he's not it either. It's then that a
falls across them. Billy looks up to see...
Dr. Grant! Grant has just returned, a bag over his shoulder.
Mr. Brennan.
Billy takes one of Grant's bags, talking as they go.
How was your trip? Profitable?
We'll be broke in four weeks.

Three weeks. I had to rent some equipment. The cross into one of the tents, which only has two "wall a dust-taped table, a dusty Macintosh is feeing data into strange machine the size of a dorm refrigerator. A mechan back and forth across a tray of fine sand.
You rented an automated litter box.

It's a rapid prototyper. I feed in the scan data from the raptor skull, than the computer breaks it into thousands of slices which this thing prints, one layer on top of the other. It's the future of paleontology.
Not if it can't dig. The arm stops and suddenly the tray of sand shakes, dropp through holes in the bottom to reveal an object the size a person's fist.

I give you a raptor's resonating chamber. Grant hates technology, but he can't help but be amazed b result. He lifts the strange object up, shaking out the remaining sand. Billy puts it to his lips and blows through it like a con The resulting SOUND is unique and piercing, the cry of an non-existent animal. Grant is speechless with excitement. uses it again and again, producing different SOUNDS and variations. In the distance, flocks of birds rise to the sky and fly Billy looks up to see a MAN and a WOMAN getting out of a Cadillac. Cheryl is pointing them in the direction of t tent. BILLY (cont'd)                                  (falsely casual)
Oh, I forgot to tell you. Some visitors wanted to come by and talk        to you. I  told them you'd be happy to see them.  maybe even have dinner with them.
Absolutely not.
They're here.
What? Only now does Grant realize these two people Who were walking up to them. Putting on a friendly smile, Billy goes up to them.
Dr. Grant?
Yes?
(extending his hand)
Paul Kirby. Kirby Enterprises (reaching into his pocket)
My card. PAUL KIRBY is a talkative optimist with no "off" switch. His wife AMANDA KIRBY, just as friendly, is harder to read. There seems to be exhaustion behind her eyes.
What can I do for you, Mr. Kirby?
Well sir, I am a great admirer of yours, and I have an extremely interesting  proposition to discuss. Would you let my wife  and I take you to have dinner tonight? Our treat.
You know, I've been traveling and I'm very tired. Maybe some other time.
I guarantee it'll be worth your while. Behind Kirby, Bill furtively rubs his thumb and fingers together, indicating the guy is loaded. Grant musters a weak smile.
It's be my pleasure.

location: HELL CREEK BAR AND GRILL, JORDAN, MT

text: Theyre only halfway through the entree, but Grant is read bolt. It's only Billy who's keeping him from being rude. over to Paul and Amandas table and sit down.
First off let me say as a dinosaur enthusiasts, Amanda and I have admired your work for years.
It is truly, whats the word? Inspiring.
Thank you. It's everything Grant can do just to be polite. He desper wants to leave and get back to his dig.
Amanda and I, well, we just love the outdoors. Heck we've been on pretty much any adventure tour they can come up with: Galapagos, K2, the Nile...
We even have two seats reserved aboard the first commercial moon flight. Billy nudges Grant.
Hmmm.
Now, for our wedding anniversary this year we wanted to do something really special, something... He places his hand on his wife's.
...once-in-a-lifetime.

We've arranged for a private airplane to take us flying over Isla Sorna. And we want you to be our guide. The Kirby's look to Grant as if they've offered him an am gift. But Grant just sighs and smooths the tablecloth.
That's a very nice offer, Mr. Kirby, but I'm afraid I'm much to busy. If you like I can refer you to a number of highly qualified...
No, no, see Dr. Grant, you're the best. You've seen these animals in the flesh. No one else has come close to you.

I'm flattered, but I've taken this little adventure tour. And with the air restrictions they've imposed after the incident in San Diego, you cant fly low enough to see anything of interest. Paul is momentarily stymied, but Amanda rallies.
You see, that's just the thing. Paul and I have special permission to fly low.
How low?
Well, I'm no aviation specialist. But I do know it's hell of a lot lower than anyone else.
From what I understand, it's pretty much whatever we want.
That's hard to believe.
Let's just say that through my business -- imports/exports, emerging markets -- I've made some friends in high places. In this case, the Costa Rican government.
Dr. Grant, you don't know how important it is for us to have you come along. It would make all the difference. Grant is trying to find another way to say no, when Paul out his checkbook.
And of course, we're prepared to make a sizeable contribution to your research here. Billy looks at Grant. Don't say no. PAUL (cont'd)
I can write all kinds of numbers on this check. Just tell me what exactly it would take. We HOLD ON a conflicted Dr. Alan Grant.
A SMALL AIRPLANE - a Beechcraft Kingair 200 Turboprop, to exact - cruises through clear blue skies.
Grant re-settles, trying to get comfortable. Billy is acr from him, finishing cleaning his camera lenses before put them back in the ragged case.
Even with what I pay you, you could get a better bag.
No way. This is lucky. Couple years ago some buddies and I went hang gliding off these cliffs in New Zealand. Updraft sent me right into the side. BOOM!
That does sound lucky.
It was this strap alone that saved my life. Got caught on a rock as I was falling.
Reverse-Darwinism. Survival of the most idiotic. Because he hasn't really said it...
Listen Alan, I really appreciate you bringing me along.
The bones will be there when we get back. That's the nice thing about them. They never run away. (beat)
And besides, you got me into this. I don't intend to be alone with these people.

sitting near the front of the plane. Paul draws a long, n breath and looks at Amanda. She seems just as tense. Finally finding a comfortable position, Grant puts his ha his eyes, ready to take a nap. Done with his camera, Billy turns to someone just off scr

So how do you know the Kirby's? and we reveal... Mercenary Cooper, the weapons specialist we met earlier. wearing sunglasses so dark you can't tell whether he's st at you or fast asleep. He doesn't answer. Did he even hear? And then --
Through our church.
What Religion?
Uh...the one that worships God and believes in being Good.
The plane continues onward.
Grant slowly wakes in his chair, groggy. All the other passengers are fast asleep. Then Grant turns to his right
sits besides him. The dinosaur eyes him curiously, then o his mouth...
Alan. And than it STRIKES.
Grant wakes up with a start, disoriented. Billy is leanin him.
Alan. We're almost there. The adrenaline still surging through him, Grant turns and THROUGH THE WINDOW. Clouds obscure the view, than parts reveal
rising majestically out of the water.
We watch the plane descend sharply to the island.
In various combinations, Grant and Billy, Paul and Amanda out the windows at the amazingly green island. Cooper looks out through a window of his own.
Here we find the rest of the crew from the junkyard. Nash piloting. A VOICE comes over their radio headsets.
(Spanish accent)

Unidentified aircraft approaching Isla Sorna, this is San Juan approach. You are flying in restricted airspace. Immediately turn to the coordinates two-zero-zero. I repeat redirect to... A look from Nash then Udesky switches off the radio.
The plane now descends to a mere hundred feet above the treetops.
Paul puts his hand atop Amanda's as they stare intently o window. Billy looks to Grant.
Admit it. You're excited. Grant will admit nothing. Calling back from the cockpit...
Cooper! Yell up if you see anything!
(yelling back)
No, I thought I'd keep it to myself. Suddenly Grant spots...
There. There! An Apatosaur. Look at the coloration.

head_text.subj: EXT. ISLA SORNA GRASSY FIELD CONTINUOUS DAY

text: An Apatosaur is grazing on the grass.
(amazed)
I'm so use to seeing bones. It's weird to see skin.
Mr. and Mrs. Kirby! If you look out the right you can see... But Paul just waves him away with a hand, staring intentl his window. We HOLD ON Grant a moment, thinking that odd.
Udesky puts down his binoculars.
South shore is clear. The rest is rock.
Are we on?
We're on.
Looking out the window, Grant notices they're flying awfu low. Just then, he hears a MECHANICAL HUM and a LOW RUSH outside. Now wanting to believe --
That's not the landing gear? Paul, Amanda and Cooper don't respond.
What you're... (realizing)
You can't land. Paul turns back to him.
Dr. Grant if you'd just sit tight, we'll explain this all in a jiffy.
This plane can not land!

It's going to be all right. Just... Grant is out of his seat, heading for the cockpit. He'll the controls if he has to. Cooper grabs him, pulling him back. Grant starts to strug but he's certainly no match. A well-practiced fist hits h dead on. CUT TO BLACK.
we hear Amanda's voice, strangely distant but amplified.
Eric! Eric! Are you there honey? Ben! Erriccc! Her calls continue as we FADE UP to...
GRANT'S P.O.V. -- blurry and disorientated. He finds hims on the floor of the plane. Seeing him come to, Billy helps him slowly get up. Grant' is pounding.
Tell me we didn't land. By his expression, we see Billy would have to lie.
I think they're looking for someone.

The jungle has almost reclaimed this patchy vine-covered runway. The airplane is parked at one end. Nash, Udesky, and Cooper are checking their weapons. Amanda is at the edge of the tarmac calling into the jung BULLHORN. Billy and a groggy Grant emerge from the airplane. Paul t over.
Dr. Grant, are you alright? I'm sorry we had to be so... The three mercenaries are now walking into the jungle wit their guns.
What the hell is going on? What are they doing?
Establishing a perimeter. Making it safe. These guys are really good. One of them was a Green...
Mr. Kirby, trust me, on this island, there is no such thing as safe. We have to get back in this plane... Grant looks to Amanda, who shouts through a bull horn.
(on-bullhorn)
And tell your wife to stop making so much noise! We're food to these damn  animals.
(yelling)
Amanda, Honey! Dr. Grant says it's a bad idea!
(on the bullhorn)
What?
(pointing broadly at Alan)
He says it's a bad idea!
(on the bullhorn)
What's a bad idea? As in on cue, there is a DEAFENING ROAR from the jungle. Everyone turns toward the sound and freezes.
(to Alan)
What was that? Grant doesn't answer, still listening to the reverberatio Then a couple shots are heard.
(low)
Is it a rex?
I don't think so. Billy and Paul breathe a small sign of relief.
Sounds bigger. Nash and Udesky come RUNNING out of the jungle, headed fo the plane.
We gotta go, now!
What's the problem? Can't you guys...? As Udesky and Nash sprint past Paul in interrupted by a second, closer, DEAFENING ROAR. He pales.
Udesky waits by the door, hustling everyone inside. Nash hurries into the cockpit. Everyone scrambles to a seat. A climbs next to Paul.
We can't just...
Don't worry, honey. We'll circle around and come back. Udesky closes the door.
What about the other guy?
Coop's a professional. He can handle himself. A blood-curdling SCREAM echoes through the jungle followe MACHINE GUN FIRE.
(yelling back)
We're going! Udesky climbs into the copilot's seat, and Nash revs the
The plane starts down the runway.
The passengers bounce in their seats as the plane picks u speed down the overgrown strip.
Suddenly, two hundred yards ahead of the plane,
emerges from the jungle. He stands in the middle of the r waving one arm wildly. His second, badly injured arm hang limp by his side.
Come on, Nash. Slow down, buddy.
Nash spots Cooper, shoots a glance at the airspeed indica
Coop, you know I can't do it pal. He slams down full throttle in an attempt to reach flying Seeing that Nash has no intention of stopping, Paul shout the cabin.
What are you doing? That's Mr. Cooper!
We are looking down on Cooper from behind. As the plane approaches,

falls over the injured mercenary. Then with brutal speed, ENORMOUS BEAST seizes him in its massive jaws and lifts h into the air. From this angle we get only a glimpse of a long crocodili snout, powerful clawed forearms and spiny sail rising fro creature's back.
All eyes are on the creature as it devours Cooper. Amanda away in horror.
Oh, my God! Paul, my God!

Looking through the windshield, we see the creature is di in the path of the plane. Nash pulls back on the stick. The plane rises. The left propeller clips the flank of the enormous dinosaur, SNAPPING the blade. Blood sprays the windshield and side windows.
The turboprop banks into the jungle, out of control.

The passengers are thrown about as the craft CRASHES thro trees, tearing off a wing and pieces of the tail. Finally coming to rest in the jungle canopy, the plane se in the trees. SILENCE. The passengers slowly recover and have a look around. Fol blocks most windows, making it impossible to see out.
Is anyone hurt? Checking themselves, everyone seems pretty much intact. Still thinking of himself as in charge...
Quiet! We're okay. Let's everybody just stay put. He attempts to turn on the cockpit radio, but it's dead.
Who's got the sat-phone?

Right here! Paul hands the bulky phone up to Nash, who dials out. Grant unstraps himself, climbs to the back to the side do The door opens a few inches before hitting a branch. He looks out the and lets out a quiet gasp as the ground THIRTY FEET BELOW. He quickly shuts and latches the door. CLOSE ON the sat-phone. pressed against Nash's ear.
We're sorry. All circuits are busy. Please try your call again later...
Shit!

What is it? What's the matter? Amanda SCREAMS. A huge reptilian face appears in the cockpit window. Ever else SCREAMS now. The plane LURCHES - and we hear a deep GROWL. The passengers hold tight, paralyzed. Nash buckles himsel his seat. Suddenly, the plane is YANKED from the side to side. Batt way and that, the terrified passengers tightly grip their seats. Finally, the horrible sounds of WRENCHING METAL as the no the plane is RIPPED RIGHT OFF. Nash and Udesky are suddenly sitting in open air. The nos the plane is tilting downwards, the jungle floor far belo The passengers hang almost vertically in their seats, Debris tumbles out the open end of the plane, some of it striking Nash in the head. Udesky unbuckles his seat belt and climbs back up into th cabin. Nash follows. Suddenly, a long snout with dagger-like teeth pushes past cockpit seats, opens wide, and

on Nash's legs. The pilot CRIES OUT in agony. The others passengers grab his arms, trying to pull him back. But it's no use. The d rips Nash out of their grasp and down the aisle. Nash desperately grabs on to the seat cushion, then watch horror as the fabric RIPS AWAY. He's pulled out of the pl dropped to the ground. A giant foot steps in the way as t of the creature reaches down and quickly devourers the sc pilot. It's horrifying sight, but no one can turn away. Pleased with the appetizer, the creature comes back for t main course. Grant tries to force open the jammed rear door. Billy tri help, but the door won't budge. The dinosaur JAMS its snout into the fuselage and lunges Amanda in the first row. She yanks her legs back as the j SNAP SHUT. Behind Amanda, Billy reaches forward, UNSNAPS her seat be and pulls her into the next row back. The others unstrap their belts and crowd into the rear of passenger compartment. The shift in weight sends the fuselage tipping backwards.
The plane breaks free of the tree limbs and DROPS tail-fi the jungle floor. It SLAMS hard, then flips over onto its roof.

The passengers are prowled on the ceiling of the plane, d by the impact. Everyone is cut and bruised. Out of the open cockpit, they see two approaching dino fe A window near Amanda fogs over with condensation. when it clears, she finds herself looking right into enormous eye Then all hell breaks loose as the plane is SLAMMED across jungle clearing. The passengers are hammered against the walls of the plan tumbling like socks in a dryer. Debris, seats and luggage everywhere.
The plane comes to an abrupt halt as it SMASHES into a tr A gargantuan FOOT steps on the fuselage and FLATTENS it l paper tube.
Inside, windows EXPLODE, raining glass over the passenger the walls compress, Udesky becomes trapped in the rear of plane, the others in front.

Over here! Udesky dives into the narrowing gap, and Billy pulls him rest of the way through. Billy is as terrified as the rest of them, but he thrives this rush of adrenaline. Then a huge CLAW digs into the skin of the fuselage and b to slowly PEEL the plane open. Grant looks up in dread at widening tear.

This way! Grant leads the group out the open end of the cockpit. Th make a mad dash for the jungle. A tremendous ROAR causes Billy to look behind him. He can help but steal a glimpse of this terrifying, but utterly fascinating, animal. Grant yanks him forward.

With Grant in the lead, and Udesky taking up the rear, th tears through the jungle. Concealed by the dense undergrowth, the unseen dinosaur b down on them -- mowing down the young trees which TOPPLE around them. Grant spots a grove of

and leads the group into it. The dinosaur cannot fit between the trunks. It ROARS at the fleeing humans, searching desperately for a route aft them. The group continues their relentless pace, putting as muc distance as they can between themselves and the beast. Pa Kirby looks like he's about to have a heart attack. Even is gasping for air. They stop, thinking they've outrun it. Grant directs the group through some underbrush and into
Our friends stop dead in their tracks. Amanda stifles a c Before them lies an immense unmoving SAUROPOD.
Don't worry. It's dead. Then a full-grown bull
rises up behind the carcass. It was feeding, its mouth mo with blood and carrion. Grant FREEZES.
Nobody move a muscle. Remember: the T-Rex tracks motion. Obeying, the group FREEZES for a few long beats. Then Ude takes off running. And T-Rex ROARS. Everyone runs. T-Rex is right behind them.

Dashing back the way they came, the group suddenly comes to face with -- THE FIRST MONSTER. We now get our first full unobstructed view of the gigant creature, SPINOSAURUS AEGYPTICUS. Over forty feet long an twenty-five feet high, the dinosaur has a bony sail along back. Its head is crocodilian with rows of long, curving Sinewy six foot arms terminate in three fingers hands wit fourteen inch claws. Nowhere else to run, the group scatters into the brush as two behemoth predators rush forward, their ROARS thundero Paul and Amanda scramble into one direction, Billy and Ud the other. But Grant can't go anywhere - his foot is stuc between two branches. He manages to free himself as the two dinosaurs approach. That one time was just the bumper.
He would have been, safe. Completely, entirely, suffocatingly safe. (beat)

I would have him to see more of the world than Enid, Oklahoma. I wanted to see more of the world than Enid, Oklahoma. And so yes, it's my fault that this happened. I'm sorry that you have to be here. Really looking at her...
I'm not sorry at all.
Morning on Isla Sorna. A low mist hangs tight to the fore floor as Eric seals up his hideaway for hopefully the las They start walking. Eric pulls something out of his pocke shows it off to Grant.
Know what this is?
(takes it)
A raptor claw. I use to have one. A fossil.
Mine's new. Grant hands it back. Eric is becoming more and more a normal thirteen-year old There's an innocence to him that's coming back.
How much of this island have you explored?
I stayed pretty close to the compound, Figured if anyone came to look for me, that's where they'd start.
We need to head for the coast.
Are you sure?
Why?
Closer you get to the water, the bigger things get.
Billy and Amanda wait for Paul as he comes out of the bus hiking up his shorts. Trying to take charge...
We need to stick to the plan. Head for the coast.
What about Eric and Dr. Grant?
Going to the coast was Alan's idea. If he's alive, thats where he's headed.
What about Eric? Billy represses his instinct to say Eric's dead.
(rationalizing)
He's probably has a better chance by the coast as it is. Figures that all the big dinosaurs would live in the center of the island. (to Billy)
Right?
Sure.

As Grant and Eric walk, both stop, hearing a strange soun for a change, it's not an ominous one. It's a human one. A phone is RINGING, very faintly. Without a word to each Grant and Eric decide its coming from the right.

Paul is picking the briars out of his socks as they hike, risking tripping on every step. Then Amanda stops short. the first to hear it: THE SAME RINGING. After a beat, everyone else can hear it too. And recongni finally lights on Paul's face...
My phone. Suddenly, Paul frantically searches his pockets as the ot anxiously watch.
You had the phone the whole time?
Where is it?
I don't know. I don't have it with me.
When did you have it last?
I don't remember
Think. And Paul wracks his memory...
The plane. I got a call on the plane, put it in my coat pocket, and... Bust suddenly, he stops, his face is lighting with an awf realization. Amanda couldnt bear the wait...
What?...WHAT!?
I loaned it to Nash. He must have had it on him when he... The hideous implication of his words slowly sink in.
Still following the faint RINGING, Grant and Eric turn to

moving through the low trees. We recognize it as the back spinosaurus. We might think it's any random spinosaurus, except for the RINGING coming from somewhere inside it. Grant and Eric press back against a tree, keep perfectly still as they hear the THOOOOMB, THOOOOMB, THOOOMB of the creature's footsteps reverberating. It's tail RUSTKES aga the brush. It's moving behind them, and it's close. We hear the RINGING move from left to right as it passes. far, its has no idea they're there. Looking across the clearing, Eric is startled to see
are no more than 20 yards away, also hiding. An involunta reflex, Eric calls out...

Mon! Dad! Grant immediately covers the boys mouth. But it's to late The dinosaur has stopped. We still can't see it. We don't close it is. Paul and Amanda spot Eric with Grant. They're a thousand emotions at once: relieved, disbelieving, terrified, over They want to run to him, to yell out to him, but the mons close. Grant takes his hand off Eric's mouth. They both stay completely silent. All this time, the sat-phone is RINGING. Than it stops. And after an agonizing beat, the beast moves. At first we not sure which direction it's headed, but finally we can its moving away. Once the sail is finally out of sight, Eric breaks from G hold and dashes to his parents' arms. They coop him up. H him, kiss him, their affection unquenchable. He's crying.
(reassuring him)
Sweetheart, you're okay. (reassuring herself)
You're okay. (disbelieving)
You're okay.
Never had a doubt. Never did. Us Kirby men, we stick around, huh?
We do. Looking at her grubby son, Amanda licks her shirttail, tr to rub his face clean.
Honey, there's not enough spit in the world for that. She LAUGHS. It's the first times she's laughed in two mon Billy crosses the distance to Grant.
We need to keep moving.
Alan, I want to tell you that I'm so sorry about the...
Billy, I can't talk to you now. He walks off. Billy follows him.
Please, okay? Just yell at me. Call me an idiot. An asshole. Stupid. Tell me I screwed up because I know I did. Grant doesn't respond.

I thought if we could get a raptor back to the mainland, we could get serious money for it. Enough to fund the digging for 10 years. More. Whatever it took. Grant shakes his head, disgusted, But doesn't stop.
You have to believe me. I did it with the best intentions.
(finally turning on him)
Some of the worst things imaginable have been done with the best intentions. You rushed in with no thought to the consequences, to yourself or anyone else. (finally)
You're no better than the people who built this place. Grant keeps walking, leaving Billy with his guilt.

The group enters a structure with giant windows designed look into the canyon beyond -- only there's nothing to se thick fog. Toward the center of the room, a spiral staircase that le a lower level. With Billy lagging, Grant approaches the stairs and peers the circular opening in the floor. There is not much to s fog, a glint of sunlight.

Step by step, Grant leads the group down a rusty spiral staircase below the observation room. The stairs end in a level. Although we're technically outside, this whole pla strangely enclosed. There's a thick fog at this level -- clouds, really -- bu below we can see the river. And at its banks, a barge.
We climb down to the barge and follow the river out to the ocean. With any luck, the Costa Rican coast guard will pick us up.
Then we go home?
Then we go home. Grant leads everyone down a RAMP to --

A catwalk branches off, a SET OF STAIRS continuing down t along the canyon wall. Grant starts down the stairs. He's only taken a few steps the rusty staircase suddenly BREAKS BENEATH HIS FEET. Paul grabs him in the nick of time. The staircase vanish the fog. CLANFING AGAINST the canyon wall. After a few mo seconds of silence, they hear the CRASH far below.
You okay? Grant nods and looks in the other direction.
How about if we try this way? Their only other option is a precarious catwalk that disappears into the mist.
Do you think it goes all the way across?
One way to find out. The only way to get his-near-fall is to push ahead. But h stomach turns at being so high. Amanda follows. The catwalk creaks and groans, listing slightly. She freezes mid-stride.
(glancing back)
We'd better do this one at a time. Amanda steps of and Grant carefully pushes forward, disappearing into the thick fog. The others listen to the CREAKING of the catwalk until it ABRIPTLY. SILENCE.
Dr. Grant? More silence. Then, out of the fog, a distant voice call
Come on over. One at a time. Amanda steps tentatively forwards. Eric is clinging to he
Eric, its okay. You'll be right behind me.
We're not going anywhere, I promise. As Paul holds Eric, and Amanda shares a look. Amanda
We're all together now, Eric. Eric reluctantly releases her mother. Amanda starts to cr

Grant has stopped at a lateral support across the catwalk, trying to get the sense of where they are and wh purpose this place may have served. Seeing that the support beams are brace high arched walls mesh, it becomes obvious that we are inside this vast construction. Amanda emerges from the mist and turns back to the catwal
(calling out)
Okay! Come on, Eric!
Eric is next to go across. He's still tentative.
How 'bout if I...
No, I can do it. Billy and Paul look on as Eric disappears into the vapor.
(muttering to himself)
That's it Eric. Nice and easy...

Eric slowly gropes his way forward. He feels a GUST OF WI a HEAVY THUD ahead on the catwalk which now sways beneath him. Regaining his balance, Eric peers forward, but the fog pr him from seeing more than fifteen feet ahead. There is an SILENCE. Eric calls out timidly.
Mom?

Across the canyon, Grant moves across the later support. his hand on the railing, he sends a white, hardened subst dropping into the mist. Looking up, Grant notices a large strut, covered with the substance. Realizing what it could be.
Oh, my God.
What is it?
A bird cage. Then, the sound of Eric SCREAMING.
Eric watches as A LOOMING SHAPE emerges from the fog -- a nightmarish vision stalking purposefully forward.

standing over seven feet high, walks upright on clawed fe thirty foot wings folded bat-like at his side. The creature sees Eric and fixes him with a demonic glare Eric CRIES OUT and dashes back down the teetering catwalk The Pteranodon ruses to its feet, spreads its thirty-foot and flies directly at him.

head_text.subj: AT THE OTHER END OF THE CATWALK

text: Hearing Eric's SCREAMS, Paul charges onto the catwalk, searching in the fog.
Eric!
It won't hold! Suddenly,
emerges from the fog, racing toward his father. And then
swoops out of the fog, opens its giant rear claws, and sn the terrified boy from the catwalk. Paul Kirby watches in stunned, abject horror as the Ptera carries Eric directly overhead --

The flying reptile struggles with the boy's weight. Paul watches helplessly as Eric is carried high across the can Paul runs back alone the catwalk in a desperate attempt t Eric in sight. Billy stays behind, moving back up the platform to try to keep the dinosaur in view. With a new idea, he races back stairs to the observation room. He has a way to save Eric When he reaches the canyon wall, Paul turns a corner and along another enclosed catwalk leading deeper into the ca Grant and Amanda now come pounding down the catwalk tryin catch up with Paul.
(shouting)
Paul! Where is he? Can you see him?
(shouting back)
I'm trying! That thing took him down this way!
Split up!

carries Eric deeper into the canyon. The creature's wings steadily overhead, and the WIND is fierce. Eric looks dow sees the river far below. The Pteranodon swoops over an isolated outcropping of roc the end of the canyon and drops Eric into --

A large bowl of mud and branches the size of a satellite Eric lands right on top of a pile of dinosaur bones picke clean. Mixed among is one human skull. Before Eric has time to cry out, he looks up to find
closing in on him with sharp-edged beaks. He picks up the human skull and whips it to the hatchling They easily duck it and keep coming.
Grant looks up to see Billy leaning out over the edge of observation platform. He suddenly realizes what Billy is to do.
Billy SHOUTS BACK, an excited-terrified grin on his face.
Billy jumps off the railing and DROPS TOWARDS THE CANYON BELOW. Grant, Paul and Amanda watch as Billy FALLS past them lik stone, plummeting towards certain death. But then --

blossoms above him. Not only does it slows Billy's descent, but he even manag catch an updraft and begin to rise. He struggles to control the parasail, swooping dangerousl close to the canyon wall, barely avoiding it. Up ahead he catches sight of Eric and steers towards him.
Eric struggles to keep away from the hatchlings. But ther no way out of this nest. Billy SWOOPS overhead, but he's too high to reach Eric.
He circles around to make another attempt.
Paul rounds the corner and finally catches sight of Eric nest, some fifty feet below, fighting off the hatchlings.

Hang on, Eric! Paul sees an outcropping he could jump onto from here. It big leap, though, he might not make it. He steels himself the jump, then chickens out. Grant and Amanda come up behind him. Suddenly,
CRASH LANDS on the catwalk enclosure about them -- right to a gaping hole in the mesh. The catwalk GROANS with the extra weight. The pteranodon JAMS its head through the hole, SNAPPING a them.

Billy circles, making his approach. In the nest, Eric kicks at the hatchlings, but they're undeterred. Billy and Eric will only have one chance. As Billy swoops past, Eric jumps and grabs onto his boot. yanked up and out of the nest. But than, MOTHER PTERANODO shoots past, tearing out a piece of the parasail in its b

The pteranodon who landed on the top of the catwalk conti SNAP through the hole in the enclosure. Finally the reptile's massive weight proves to much, and entire section of the catwalk BREAKS FREE of the canyon w and FLIPS OVER LATERALLY. Amanda, Grant and Paul are able to hang on, but so is the pteranodon, who now climbs their way.
His parasail badly damaged, Billy tries to keep aloft. He as low as he dares, he yells to Eric --

Let go! Terrified, Eric falls into the river safely. He surfaces, immediately swimming to shore. Trying to gain altitude, Billy bends hard to the right. B rigging is too badly damaged. He flies right into the can wall, hitting hard. Instead of tumbling down to the river, he finds himself swinging from his harness - the parasail snagged on a roc spire above him.

Paul, Grant and Amanda struggle to stay away from the pteranodon as it moves towards them. Suddenly. the far end of this inverted section of catwalk detaches from the canyon wall and SWINGS DOWNWARD. The force of the action sends the three tumbling directly towards the pteranodon. Miraculously, they manage to avoid its open beak. But the are all sent plummeting toward the river below.
They hit the water hard, resurfacing moments later. The current is carrying them downstream.

The two pteranodons who were pursuing Billy now land on n ledges and consider how best to dispatch their prey. Billy frantically tries to unhook his harness, but the te is so tight from his own weight that he can't loosen the buckles.

Paul and Amanda emerge from the water by the canyon wall find their son hiding behind a rock, searching the skies Billy. Amanda takes Eric tightly in her arms, and Paul urges the keep moving. Up ahead, the mesh of the aviary meets the r Wading the shore, Grant now scans the canyon, searching f Billy. It doesn't take long to spot him.

Billy continues to struggle with the harness but to no av The doomed young man is suspended high up on the canyon w like a modern Prometheus, an entire FLOCK of pteranodons gathering around him preparing to peck away his liver. An everything else. A MAMMOTH PTERANADON has landed beside him and looks him straight in the eye. The gigantic creature lunges at him. Billy dodges away as he can. The pteranodon's frustrated bite severs a crucial juncture on Billy's harness, and Billy is able to wriggle
Eric, Amanda, Paul and Grant watch in amazement as Billy last to PLUNGE DOWN into the river.

He made it! Billy bobs to the surface and spots the group downstream. waves and begins to swim towards them. Soon he nears the and gets to his feet, wading as he comes. Grant, Paul, Amanda and Eric hurry to meet him. Grant is overjoyed to see him alive. But his smile quickl fades as he sees
diving down from above in angry pursuit of their lost pre
Billy, look out! Billy glances behind him. He races forward, motioning fro companions to turn around.

Get back! Get back! Just then Billy is knocked down by the lead pteranodon. I strikes from behind with a brutal, calculated beak to the Billy stumbles and falls to the ground. Grant rushes forward with Paul right after him. Amanda ta Eric to safety down river. Billy SCREAMS as the ENTIRE FLOCK of pteranodons now swar around him, picking him apart with their beaks and claws.
Billy!

It's no use, Dr. Grant. No use. Grant can't take his eyes off Billy, whose BLOOD stains t water rushing by. And now several pteranodons are heading their way. Diffic as it is to leave Billy behind, Grant and Paul make a run Just as the pteranodons are about to swoop in for the kil and Paul dive back into the river...
...and resurfaces on the far side of the mesh aviary wall for air. Just behind them, the mammoth

CRASHES into the mesh. It tears at the steel, actually ri it in one place. At the dock up ahead, Amanda and Eric have found a rusty, waterlogged barge that's somehow still floating. Carrying tarp-covered cage, the boat was meant for transporting di up and down the river. Amanda pushes them away from the dock as Alan and Paul cl on board.

The current takes the craft downstream, letting us get ou first good look at the incredible AVIARY. It's a vast, domed mesh structure that spans the entire c In all, a feat of remarkable engineering and unmistakable hubris. Catching their breath, our four survivors look at the cag were caught in.
Yanking the starter rope one final time, Paul finally get engine to turn over, PUTTERING along. Amanda is beside hi bailing water.
My own kid was right in front of me and I didn't do a damn thing.
You couldn't have made that jump.
I should have tried. It should have been me on that beach back there, not Billy.
How would you have helped Eric? (he can't answer)
He needs you, Paul. He needs us.
He could have died.
But he didn't. And neither did you. And I'm glad about that.
Grant is beside Eric, keeping watch, but also feeling the of Billy's death.
Do you have any kids?
No. Although I've studied them in the wild. Eric looks over, not sure what that means.
I have a theory that there's two kinds of boys. Those who want to be astronomers and those who want to be astronauts.
I want to be an astronaut.

See, I was the opposite. I never understood why anyone would want to go into space. It's so dangerous. You do one thing wrong and you're dead. The astronomer -- or the paleontologist -- get to study these amazing things from a place of complete safety. And truthfully, everything you really need to learn, you can learn it from the ground.
But then you never get to go in space.

Exactly. The difference between imagining how things might be and seeing how they really are. To be able to touch them. That's what Billy wanted to do. The barge starts to round a bend. On the bow, Grant and E are the fist to see something remarkable. Eric GASPS, unprepared. We don't know yet what they see. GRANT (cont'd)

I can blame the people who made this island. But I can't blame the people who want to see it. To study it. At the rear of the barge, Paul just now sees what's ahead struck, he slows the motor and motions for Amanda to take look. And so do we.

The setting sun illuminates an incredible valley filled w dinosaurs. We see armored ANKYLOSAURS with clubbed tails. Duck-billed CORYTHOSAURS. We float under the gigan arching necks of eighty-foot BRACHIOSAURS. With the mist from the river and the play of light, we're witnessing a kind of primal Eden. GRANT (cont'd)
How's a boy suppose to resist this?

A FULL MOON passes behind clouds. THUNDER quietly rumbles LIGHTNING flickers in the distance. Paul is still at the wheel. The river is narrower here, a cautions must be taken to avoid the banks. As the barge begins to round another bend. a FAMILIAR HIG PITCHED SOUND pierces the darkness. Muffled but unmistaka it is the RINGING SAT-PHONE. All exchange looks of sheer PANIC, expecting Spinosaurus leap out at any moment. Grant scans the river banks.

Keep quiet. Paul cuts the motor, and time seems to stop as the four s posed for action. The barge finishes rounding the curve, and the ringing gr LOUDER. The suspense is excruciating until finally... Their eyes widen at some horrifying sight, more horrifyin than anything they've yet seen. SEVEN MOUNDS OF DINOSAUR DUNG sit on the patch off treele ground just beyond the river bank. As our friends consider the sight, an idea comes to them almost simultaneously. With Eric still in the boat, Amanda, Paul, and Alan jump the river and rush to the bank.
The three companions sprint towards the source of the RIN
Find it before it stops ringing! And bracing themselves and hocking their breath, they PLU their arms into their respective dung-heaps. After a few moments of this disgusting search...

I've got something. I think I've got something! All turn to Paul. Clearing away the clinging defecation, holds up to a beeper. And still the phone RINGS. Returning to their bleak task, they shovel the excrement their arms. Finally:
I've got it! I've got it! Grant snatches the RINGING SAT-PHONE from Amanda's hands, presses a button, and puts it to his ear.

You too can own a time share in beautiful Guadalajara. Enjoy a meal in one of our four star restaurants, explore our coral reefs, or just walk on the beach... The Kirbys hear the recorded voice and let out a collecti heavy sigh. Grant shuts off the phone. In all the excitement, none of them notice a fierce horne CARNOTAUR right behind them. The giant creature ROARS, re to eat them. But as it gets in close, it smells them. Even a dinosaur eat something that is covered in shit. After a beat, the Carnotaur turns and walks away, back into the jungle.
Can't help but be a little offended.
CLOSE ON the cleaned satellite phone's display. The batte level indicator is FLASHING.
Whatever you do, don't call the U.S. Embassy. They won't do a God Damn thing.
Well, we don't exactly have a Costa Rican phone book here, so it will have to be somebody we know in the states. Someone we can absolutely count on to send help.
(to Amanda)
Stan.
I wouldn't trust Stan with a snowball in a blizzard. Paul glares at her. Now Eric notices something odd in the river.
What's that? The others look down in the murky water. Just below the surface,
passes beneath the boat. Then a SINGLE FISH jumps from the water. And another. And another.
Bonitas.
Something must've scared them. Another roll of THUNDER, this time much closer.

Get the motor going. Paul moves the motor and pulls the start cord. The engine sputters but won't come to life. And now the phone BEEPS. The battery is getting even weak Grant makes a quick decision and DIALS.
Who are you calling? But Grant ignores the question. RING. RING.
Pick up! Pick up!
Wearing his jammies, three-year old Charlie awkwardly pic the phone with both hands. He has the mouthpiece next to lips, but the earpiece is hanging out in space.
Hewwo?
Recognizing who it must be...
Charlie? Charlie. Get your mother. Right away! A long silence. Charlie bites his lip, looks around.
Charlie? Are you there?

Hewwo? The sat-phone BEEPS again, this time much LOUDER. Amanda and Eric watch Grant, realizing their fate may han this single call. Paul struggles without success to start motor. Then, unseen by the group, a
rises from the water just fifty yards from the barge. It' headed right to them and closing fast.
(desperate)
Charlie! It's the dinosaur man! Go get mommy, okay?
Okay. Not sure what to do with the phone, Charlie makes a logic choice and hangs it back up. He walks away to his mom.
Grant realizes he's been cut off. He's about to redial wh
The barge is RAMMED, sending everyone tumbling. Grant man to stay on top of the wheelhouse, but he loses grip on th phone, which falls on deck.

rises from the water, towering over the barge. As lightni FLASHES and thunder CRACKS, the dinosaur lets out an ear- splitting ROAR. It lunges at Grant with gaping jaws. Grant leaps out of the way just in time as the dinosaur
the entire wheelhouse.
Charlie leads Ellie into the room. Hands her the phone. O course, it's just a DIAL TONE.
Was somebody on the phone?
Dinosaur man. Ellie looks at him with confusion, then quickly checks th Caller ID box besides the phone. It's international, and number she recognizes.

Grant stays one step ahead of the Spinosaurus as the beas apart the quickly-sinking boat. It spits out the wheelhouse and bites down on the stern o boat, ripping off a chunk. Grant is heading up to the other three when he hears the phone RING.  He spots it, just about to fall into the wat Dives for it, answering...
Alan? She can hear the Spinosaurus ROAR.
Alan? Alan! But he's cut off by a SECOND ROAR, the sound of someone SCREAMING. And then the line goes dead. Ellie pales. Charlie looks at her with a smile.
(imitating)
Raaaar!

Dropping the dead phone, Grant scrambles towards the fron the boat and joins Paul, Amanda and Eric, who have taken in the dinosaur cage. The fearsome beast now lifts the stern of the boat clear the water. The cage SCRAPES across the deck and SLAMS into the gunwa toppling off the barge and INTO THE RIVER. Grant and the Kirbys are still inside.

The cage sinks. The closest to the door, Paul manages to The other three aren't as lucky. The cage rotates as it d and lands on the river bottom with the door side down, tr them inside. In the cold murky depths, they pull frantically on the ba Debris and equipment float around them. Paul surfaces out of the breath and disoriented. Spinosau pushes past the boat. If anyone is going to save his fami has to be him. And so he dives. Pushing with all his might, he manages to tip the heavy structure, just enough so Amanda, Eric and Grant can get Paul himself isn't so lucky. Spinosaurus grabs the cage and Paul, throwing both straig out of the water. Paul flies twenty feet away, further fr shore.
Spinosaurus is going after the heroic Mr. Kirby, who dive swimming underwater. He's trying to lead it away from his family.
(looking around)

Up! Up! He points to a heavy crane assembly, designed for lifting off the large boats. Now well accustomed to fleeing on command, Amanda sends Eric up first, climbing the scaffol like a jungle gym. All the while, they're trying to spot Paul. Grant is the last to climb, reaching the first section as Spinosaurus returns from the water, SLAMMING into the bas the crane. The whole assembly SHUDDERS, threatening to ri the water.
Where's Dad?

Just hold on. Try as it might, the beast can't climb the crane. So inst RAMS it, SHAKES it, trying to knock them off. Eric slips, Amanda catches him. About to shed his bag to climb higher, Grant finds one la hope. It's the resonation chamber model. A beat before he decides: It may not be the best choice, but it's the only He blows through it, the same EERIE PITCH we heard before the third try, he's able to approximate the "egg" cry he the raptors give. He keeps it up, repeating over and over Spinosaurus stops for a beat, confused How this sound cou coming from a non-raptor. But then keeps SMASHING. We can hear the mounting bolts STRAIN. Soon the whole cra will tip. But not before a MATCHING CRY is heard in the jungle. Gra stops, not certain he heard it. But there it is AGAIN. He keeps blowing. The crane is close to tipping when a single RAPTOR appear from the darkness, CHIRP-BARKING at the Spinosaur, who si bats away. But then MORE RAPTORS come. And even MORE. Soon there are dozens gathering, circling. Grant stops signaling. All three survivors watch with horrified fascination, knowing their fate is perilous no which side wins. Looking at his adversaries, Spinosaurus ROARS. And sudden the raptors attack. Spinosaurus easily handles the first few, but like ants t just keep coming. They climb up his back, slicing, into h their razor-sharp claws.

Jump! Swim for the far shore! All three drop from the crane arm into the water. Meanwhile, the fight continues. Spinosaurus rallies, shak off many of the raptors, but they just keep coming. Their hooked claws dig in, scraping the meat to the bone. Spinosaurus puts up a brave fight to the end, but finally collapses, dead. The raptors continue to shred it to ribb Then one of the raptors looks over to see the survivors swimming away. But a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. It goes its meal.
Grant is trying to move them along. still headed downstre But Eric won't budge another foot.
We have to keep looking for Dad. We have to.
I know. I know. I want to look for him too.
then we should... She kneels down, facing him. She's just as upset as he is motherhood carries the burden of remaining calm.
Let me tell you a few things about you Dad, okay? He's very very very clever, very very brave, and he loves you ever very much.
He loves you too.
Okay. He loves us very very much. And I know that right now more than anything, your Dad would want to know that we're safe. Okay? Eric nods.
We're going to get out of this, and everything's going to be all right, I promise.
Listen to your mother. Out of the darkness steps Paul Kirby. Amanda is knocked o with surprise. Eric runs to him, nearly tackling him.
Good thing I've been swimming, huh? Amanda hugs him and Eric so tightly they can't breath.
The foursome sit back on the wide beach, one facing each direction, keeping watch. A light rain is falling, b don't seem to notice. Trying to keep his boy's spirit up...

You remember when we went fishing last summer? And I was trying to put the boat in and the trailer sank? And then the tow truck came and tried to pull it out, but it got dragged in? And the truck driver threatened to knock your Dad's lights out? So I said I was the governor and he believed me? Eric really smiles, remembering the day.
Yeah. Amanda is smiling too. She had completely forgotten the incident.
That was a fun day. To Paul, after some consideration....
We should try fishing again.
You mean it?

I do. It's worth another shot. And who knows? Things might turn out differently. Her hand takes his, gently brushing off the wet sand, fin touching. It's a small thing, but it's a start. Sensing his cue to leave, Grant gets up and starts walkin the beach. Eric hurries to follow him. He speaks conspiratorially, not wanting to alarm his parents.
The lady you called, how do you know she can help us?
She's the one person I could always count on. And she's saved me more times than she realizes. I owe her everything. A long beat as they walk.
It's strikes me now I never told her that.
You should.

You're right. As they keep walking, Grant notices something rammed agai the rocks ahead. It's a speedboat, its hull ripped open f impact. And it's not just any boat either -- it's the same Dino-S boat that was pulling the parasail. Eric hasnt seen it ye Grant stops him.
Eric, do you know what happened to the boat? that brought you here? Why did it crash?
No. I couldn't see.
Do me a favor. Go back to your parents for a minute, would you? (pre-empting objections)

They look worried. Eric nods and heads back to Paul and Amanda. Grant forges approaching the speedboat wreckage. He doesn't know what find, but he needs to look. Almost reaching his parents, Eric stops. Looks out over t ocean, where he sees TWO LIGHTS. He doesn't say anything for a moment, trying to make sure they're real. They are. And they're coming closer.
(excited)
